article.title: Modelling dependency completion in sentence comprehension as a Bayesian hierarchical mixture process: A case study involving Chinese relative clauses

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate regarding the distribution of reading times at the head noun in Chinese relative clauses?
choices: Reading times are similar for subject and object relatives.
Reading times for object relatives are less spread out than for subject relatives.
Reading times for subject relatives are less spread out than for object relatives.
Reading times are highly variable for both subject and object relatives, with no clear pattern.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the distribution of reading times in Figure 2, which represents a replication study, compare to the distribution shown in Figure 1, the original study?
choices: The replication study shows a reversed pattern compared to the original study.
The replication study shows a similar skew in reading times as the original study, but with a less dramatic difference in spread.
The replication study shows no skew in reading times, unlike the original study.
The replication study and the original study show almost identical distributions of reading times.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the negative coefficient for Î²1 in Table 1 suggest, based on the coding scheme used in the study?
choices: Subject relatives are processed faster than object relatives.
Object relatives are processed faster than subject relatives.
There is no significant difference in processing time between subject and object relatives.
The distance account cannot be evaluated using this data.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of the direct-access model, what does the posterior probability of 82% for the difference between psr and por being greater than zero indicate?
choices: The model provides weak evidence that the proportion of retrieval failures is higher in subject relatives than object relatives.
The model provides strong evidence that the proportion of retrieval failures is higher in subject relatives than object relatives.
The model provides strong evidence that the proportion of retrieval failures is lower in subject relatives than object relatives.
The model provides no information about the difference in retrieval failures between subject and object relatives.
